I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In September 1997, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the Second Perennial 
Crop Development Project (SPCDP),1 which supported the development of perennial crops in 
Sri  Lanka  by  ensuring  sustainable  credit  facilities  and  effective  extension  services.  The 
Government requested a follow-on project with more focus on marketing and value addition to 
build  on  the  successful  implementation  of  SPCDP.  In  response,  the  project  preparatory 
technical assistance (TA)2 for the Agribusiness Development Project (ADP) was included in the 
country strategy and program update 2006–2008 for Sri Lanka (2005).3 The TA Fact-Finding 
Mission visited Sri Lanka in January 2006, and reached an understanding with the Government 
on the objectives, scope, financing, and implementation arrangements for the TA. The TA is 
designed to build on ADB’s earlier assistance, lessons learned, and support provided under 
SPCDP. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.        The agriculture sector accounts for about 17% of Sri Lanka’s gross domestic product and 
about  32%  of  employment.  Within  the  agriculture  sector,  the  three  leading  categories  of 
production are paddy, plantation crops, and other. The “other” category, which accounts for 47% 
of  the  production,  includes  fruits  and  vegetables,  subsidiary  field  crops,  spices,  animal 
husbandry, medicinal herbs, and floriculture.4 The agro-industrial sector comprises four main 
categories: food and other, liquor, beverages, and tobacco products. Food processing is by far 
the largest, generating 60–65% of the value of the sector’s production. While the agro-industrial 
sector  contributes  nearly  25%  of  the  value  of  industrial  production,  agro-industrial  exports 
accounted for only about 4% of industrial exports in 2004. This implies that the domestic market 
consumes  a  major  proportion  of  agro-industrial  goods.  Sri  Lanka  has  a  wide  range  of 
topography and climate, which offers a unique opportunity for growing many high-value crops—
and, therefore, for agribusiness activities. Since the late 1990s, however, the agribusiness 
sector has not realized its growth potential.  
   
3.  Lack of Effective Enabling Environment. Consultations with the private sector suggest 
that  a  major  constraint  to  commercialization  of  agriculture  is  the  lack  of  an  enabling 
environment, caused mainly by erratic agricultural policies and priorities, market imperfections, 
and inappropriate technology. The agriculture sector is central to the development policy of the 
new Government, which focuses on guaranteeing food security through paddy production, and 
recognizing the potential for diversification and commercialization of agriculture. Since 1996, the 
Government has adopted several policies to assist the growth of the agriculture sector by 
shifting from low-value to high-value production, and by improving productivity and international 
competitiveness. However, some policies were drafted but not approved, while others did not 
support the Government’s attempt to diversify agriculture. Constraints for the sector are the (i) 
restrictive land policies,5 (ii) inconsistent trade policies, (iii) restrictive quarantine regulations, 
and (iv) commodity price interventions. The Government took steps to liberalize the land market 
by transferring land titles to farmers, and by gradually replacing the deed registration system

with a system of title registration.6 In 2000, the Agrarian Services Development Act No. 46 
allowed farmers to grow alternative crops on paddy land with prior approval, although the 
burdensome process still tends to prevent farmers from diversifying.  
 
4.  Since becoming a founding member of the World Trade Organization in 1995, Sri Lanka 
has set tariffs on most agricultural goods at a uniform rate of 50%, and has freed all food 
imports of import licenses.7 However, the Government frequently adjusted import duties in an 
attempt to achieve the conflicting objectives of ensuring low food prices for consumers and high 
commodity prices for producers. This created a climate of uncertainty among agro-processors. 
In addition, the Plant Protection Act and National Seed Act are seen as major obstacles to free 
access to good seeds of improved varieties and other planting material, prerequisites for a 
successful agribusiness sector. The private sector, which participates in the market for imported 
seed, is able to sell seed, except for the paddy sector. However, the Government continues to 
operate a large network of commercial seed farms, which are underutilized due to the limited 
resources available for timely distribution of the seeds to the farmers. 
 
5.       The  civil  conflict  and  the  frequent  changes  in  Government  policies  have  slowed 
economic  and  social  reforms,  undermining  the  investment  climate.  Policy  uncertainty,  as 
reflected by the lack of consistent policies, appears to be a major barrier to the entry of new 
private  sector  investors.  The  Government  has  implemented  some  important  measures  to 
improve the policy and tax environment for private sector development in agriculture. As a 
result, the private sector—large as well as small- and medium-sized enterprises (SME) and 
trade associations—is increasingly important as a service provider in the agribusiness sector.  
 
6.     The  use  of  modern  technology  is  not  widespread  in  Sri  Lanka,  preventing  the 
improvement  of  quality  and  productivity. 8  Historically,  most  technologies  developed  in 
Government departments have not been integrated into the value chain, while public-private 
partnerships have been successful in developing needs-based technology. Furthermore, the 
lack of supportive infrastructure for marketing produce, including storage facilities, marketing 
centers, roads, and appropriate transport, hinders the development of the sector. Post-harvest 
losses due to improper handling, packaging, storage, and transport practices are estimated at 
about 25–40% for perishable items. Poor understanding of proper produce handling, inadequate 
financing for storage and transport, and lack of consumer awareness of quality standards 
hamper improvements.  
 
7.     Actors.  About 71% of farmers operate on less than 1 hectare. Thus, very small-scale 
producers, often with only home gardens, dominate commercial production. Almost all perennial 
crops are rain-fed, which leads to strong seasonality and large fluctuations in yields. During the 
season, a glut of produce results in low returns and high waste. Out of season, meanwhile, 
buyers cannot find sufficient quantities to meet orders, compelling processors to import raw 
materials. Production suffers from limited varieties, poor quality and appearance of produce, 
and the lack of marketable volumes of consistent quantity and quality. The sector also is unable 
to attract the younger generation, resulting in a labor shortage. The increase in the cost of 
inputs has combined with the labor shortage to drive up production costs. The majority of youth 
migrate to urban centers in search of higher income and more socially accepted jobs. The 
younger  generation  is willing  to  engage  in  agribusiness  activities when  new  technology is

introduced and higher profits are obtained. A significant number of SMEs are engaged in food 
processing, though few are export-oriented due to their lack of competitiveness and access to 
foreign markets. Small- and medium-scale processors have scope for expansion, if efficient 
collection and marketing networks are developed.  
 
8.       Lack  of  Supply  Chain  Management.  The  core  problem  is  the  general  failure  in 
coordinating the decisions of the private stakeholders (farmers, traders, and agro-processors) 
and service providers from the public and private sectors. Farmers are unable to make joint 
decisions regarding investment, production, and marketing due to their failure to establish links 
through effective producer organizations. Further, farmers have weak links with (i) enterprises, 
(ii)  markets,  (iii)  research,  and  (iv)  extension providers.  The  lack  of cost-effective  contract 
enforcement mechanisms discourages vertical integration between the agro-entrepreneurs and 
primary producers.9 Contract farming has been used in Sri Lanka mainly for paddy. Recently, 
however, the use of forward sales contracting has been expanded to some commercial crops to 
provide the necessary backward and forward market links for profitable smallholder production. 
Farmers fail to link to markets because of limited access to relevant market information and 
inadequate  market  infrastructure.  Due  to  the  limited  number  of  organized  retail  chains, 
entrepreneurs are also far from consumers. Moreover, the absence of proper certification, 
quality  assurance  systems,  and  infrastructure  limits  the  integration  of  production  with 
international markets. 
 
9.  Lack of Market-Oriented Support Services. The supporting industries—suppliers of 
inputs, research and extension services, collectors and distributors, wholesalers and retailers, 
and  credit  services—are  production-oriented,  inadequately  user-driven,  and  lacking  proper 
technology. Agricultural research in the past has strongly favored paddy and has been driven by 
the interests of the researchers, resulting in weak links between researchers and commercial 
farmers. Public sector extension services often are unable to provide effective services due to 
lack of funding, bureaucratic hurdles, and inadequate client orientation.10 The result is the 
absence of demand-driven research and extension systems, and the inadequate response to 
the  technology  and  knowledge  needs  of  commercially  oriented  farmers.  This  has  stopped 
farmers from diversifying into high-value production. While service providers from the private 
sector are emerging, they are oriented to the needs of corporate clients, rather than SMEs. As a 
pilot activity under the SPCDP, extension responsibilities were transferred to the private sector. 
This process has demonstrated that private sector service providers are more successful when 
they have a stake in the production cycle. 
 
10.  Access to credit is not a key constraint for most of the medium- and large-scale agro-
industries. However, it is still a problem for many of the smaller agro-industries. Strict lending 
criteria,  lack  of  suitable  collateral,  limited  borrowing  track  record,  and  lack  of  capacity  in 
preparing the business plans that banks require impair the creditworthiness of many small agro-
entrepreneurs. Most banks still view agribusiness as a risky subsector, and do not have the 
capacity to identify agribusiness lending opportunities, or to appraise and monitor agribusiness 
loans. Therefore, the growth of agribusiness SMEs requires alternative sources of capital from 
the banking system.  
 
                                                 
9  Many agro-processors purchase raw materials from the spot market, because the quality of farm produce varies 
considerably. 
10 The public extension system has been weakened by its devolution to the provincial councils, and the subsequent 
lack of coordination with research that still remains a function of the central Government. The confusion between 
central and provincial responsibilities has resulted in weak coordination among the state institutions involved in the 
sector.

4   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  TA  will  help  the  Government  design  an  agribusiness  development  project  to 
address fundamental problems in the sector. The outcome of the TA is the feasibility study that 
will  (i)  assess  in  detail  the  constraints  and  the  impediments  to  the  development  of  the 
agribusiness sector in Sri Lanka, (ii) propose strategies for overcoming the constraints that have 
been prioritized by the sector stakeholders, and (iii) recommend design and the implementation 
arrangements for the ensuing project. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. The first phase (3.5 months) will involve a 
detailed  assessment  of  the  agribusiness  sector  to  identify  its  strengths,  weaknesses, 
opportunities, and threats. The assessment will include a review of (i) the policies affecting the 
sector;  (ii)  the  factor  conditions  (infrastructure,  labor,  knowledge),  actors  (inputs  suppliers, 
farmers, traders, processors, service providers, exporters), and their links to determine the 
performance of the supply chains; (iii) the role of relevant institutions, including the private 
sector,  in  supplying  agricultural  inputs,  production,  and  marketing  to  determine  their 
effectiveness and responsiveness to industry needs; (iv) the availability and efficiency of related 
and  supporting  services  for  agribusiness  (finance,  transport,  marketing  services,  quality 
standards, and certification); and (v) the market demand and potential for different commodities 
to compete in the domestic and international markets, based on the concept of competitive 
advantage. Close attention will be paid to identifying market failures that need to be addressed 
through public investment, private sector participation, and public-private partnerships. This 
aspect will focus on marketing, market information, and processing. Based on the findings, the 
second phase (2.5 months) will involve formulation of a project for agribusiness development, 
emphasizing marketing and value addition of agricultural products. The project will not be limited 
to specific subsectors, though the TA will identify the crops with highest domestic market 
demand and export potential. The creation of high-value production clusters by region will be 
considered to facilitate marketing and processing of value-added products. The TA also will 
identify areas where the capacity of the public and private sector needs strengthening to support 
services for agribusiness development.  
 
13.   For the project to establish effective agribusiness systems by the private sector, with 
support from the Government, a new way of thinking and strategies for overcoming significant 
coordination  failures  are  needed.  This  will  require  the  creation  of  appropriate  institutional 
mechanisms.  The  project  will  be  designed  to  provide  maximum  benefit  to  small-scale 
agribusinesses. However, this will be possible only by improving the performance of the entire 
value chain. Therefore, the project must facilitate the establishment of links among farmers and 
their organized groups, research departments and certification agencies, processors, traders, 
exporters, entrepreneurs, and other decision makers. ADB is funding a TA to prepare the 
Second SME Sector Development Program (SMESDP II), which aims to design a project to 
nurture an enabling environment for SME formation, including in the agribusiness sector.11 The 
TA for ADP will use the strategic recommendations and framework set up by the SMESDP II to 
enhance the productivity, innovation, and marketing capabilities of agribusiness SMEs. 
                                                 
11 An international post-harvest and agribusiness development specialist and a national agricultural marketing 
specialist are part of the SMESDP II team.

5 
     
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide $800,000 
equivalent. The Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan, will provide a grant to 
finance the TA. The Government will finance the remaining cost of $200,000 equivalent by 
providing  office  and  equipment,  counterpart  staff,  transport,  other  facilities,  and  other 
administrative expenses. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any future project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Ministry of Agricultural Development (MOAD) will be the Executing Agency for the 
TA. Given the emphasis on coordination between ministries and private sector involvement, the 
TA will identify suitable institutional arrangements to involve other related ministries and the 
private sector in the implementation of the project. The TA will be implemented over 6 months, 
from July 2006 to December 2006. The TA will require 60 person-months of consulting services, 
including 27 person-months of international consultants and 33 person-months of domestic 
consultants. The consultants will be recruited through a consulting firm or a consortium of firms, 
selected using the simplified technical proposal of ADB’s quality- and cost-based selection 
procedure. The  draft  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the consultants  is  in  Appendix  4.  The 
consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the selection and engagement of 
domestic consultants. The TA also will provide an additional 5 person-months of short-term 
assignments for experts drawn from local industry, as needed. 
 
16.  The consultants will produce (i) an inception report within 2 weeks; (ii) an interim report 
at the end of 3 months; (iii) a draft final report at the end of 5 months; and (iv) a final report at 
the end of 6 months, incorporating feedback and comments on the draft report from ADB, the 
Government, and sector stakeholders. Tripartite meetings involving ADB, the Government, and 
the  TA  consultants  will  be  held  after  submission  of  each  report.  The  feasibility  study  will 
encourage the participation of stakeholders at each level, enabling them to be involved in the 
problem analysis, priority setting, approach, and implementation arrangements. The consultants 
will travel extensively in the field to allow consultations with all sector stakeholders through 
participatory workshops organized and carried out with the support of a professional facilitator.   
 
17.  In  support  of  the  TA  activities,  MOAD  will  provide  (i)  furnished  office  space  with 
equipment and communication facilities, (ii) vehicles, and (iii) meeting facilities and assistance 
during stakeholder consultations and/or workshops. The Government will provide counterpart 
staff, including a full-time project director for the TA. The TA will provide some equipment that 
the consultants will purchase in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. Equipment to 
be procured under the TA will be handed over to MOAD upon TA completion. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of Sri Lanka to be financed on a grant basis for preparing the Agribusiness Development 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Links to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to poverty reduction in Sri Lanka: 
 
About 80% of the population lives in the rural areas. Agricultural productivity per worker is 
stagnant,  and  many  workers  are  moving  out  of  the  agriculture  sector.  The  lack  of  young 
productivity growth has a serious long-term impact on the ability of the agriculture sector to 
provide for an expanding rural population. The agriculture sector has to grow at about four times 
the current rate of 1.4% to absorb increases in the rural population. Without such an acceleration 
in growth, poverty will increase. 
 
Agricultural  households—those  that  cultivate  crops,  raise  livestock,  or  engage  in  casual 
agricultural  wage  employment—account  for  about  45%  of  the  poorest  rural  households 
(excluding those in the estate sector). Higher-value crops account for a small percentage of the 
output  of  these  households.  For  many  crops,  the  average  yields  are  much  lower  than  in 
neighboring countries.  Given the large proportion of poorer families dependent on agriculture, 
increasing agricultural productivity, improving crop varieties and rural infrastructure, reducing 
post-harvest losses (30–40% of the output of fruits and vegetables is lost before reaching the 
market), and adopting a strategy of marketing and value addition can contribute significantly to 
poverty reduction in rural Sri Lanka. 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
About 23% of the population of Sri Lanka lives below the official national poverty line ($180 per 
year, 2002, defined as real annual per capita total food and nonfood consumption expenditure). 
Approximately 90% of those below the poverty line live in rural areas. Agriculture-based income 
for  the  poorest  agricultural  households,  those  in  the  lowest  expenditure  quintile,  is  divided 
equally between wages from casual labor and from own-farm activities. Without rapid increases 
in agribusiness activities, and the resulting increases in productivity, the living standards for the 
poorest people in the rural sector will decline, and they will be forced to migrate to other sectors. 
Welfare transfers from the Government comprise 9% of the income of this group. Increased 
agricultural value addition would reduce the need for such transfers. 
 
Richer agricultural households cultivate a larger proportion of high-value crops. The poorest 
households (bottom 20% of the expenditure quintile) utilize only 9.2% of cultivated area for the 
more profitable fruits and vegetables, while the richest 20% utilize 17% of cultivated area for 
these crops. Targeted initiatives to develop agribusiness will motivate poor farmers to shift from 
the cultivation of coarse grains with low returns to high-value crops. This would increase returns 
to the farmer, as well as agricultural wages.

Appendix 2  9 
Limited  access  to  capital,  small  landholdings,  inadequate  marketable  volumes,  and  limited 
bargaining  power  constrain  the  ability  of  poor  farmers  to  cultivate  higher-value  crops.  The 
formation of farmer societies will improve the participation of the poorest households as viable 
units in the agribusiness value chain. 
 
The incidence of poverty is highest in the provinces with the largest percentage of agricultural 
households: Uva (76%), North Central (83%), Sabaragamuwa (50%), and North East (53%). The 
expansion  of  agribusiness  in  these  areas,  with  crop  and  product-specific  targeting  where 
possible, will reduce poverty significantly.  
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
The technical assistance will involve the participation of stakeholders at various levels, including 
farmers and producers, input suppliers, processors, exporters, service providers, and traders. 
Government stakeholders that will participate include the Ministry of Agricultural Development 
and other agriculture-related ministries, as well as the departments under them, and research 
and extension organizations. The stakeholders also include unemployed rural youth. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                  No  
The implementation of the TA will require a participatory approach due to diverse interests of the 
stakeholders. The participation strategy will be developed under the TA.   
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
No adverse issues for women are anticipated. About 70% of rural women are engaged in 
subsistence agriculture, of whom 56% work as unpaid family workers. Women employed as 
agricultural labor receive 75% of the wages received by men. Women who work as unpaid family 
labor could increase incomes through involvement in high-value crops and value addition. In 
addition, women’s traditional role in agriculture is at the post-harvest stage, and any expansion in 
agribusiness activities would create more opportunities mainly for women.

which will consist of eight international and seven domestic consultants. A summary is provided

2.  Agribusiness  Development  Specialists  (one  international,  team  leader,  6  person-
months;  one  domestic,  deputy  team  leader,  6  person-months).  Working  together,  the 
international and domestic agribusiness development specialists will: 
 
(i)  Review the performance of past and continuing interventions1 in agribusiness 
development, and review sector studies. 
(ii)  Conduct  field  surveys  of  farmers,  consumers,  traders,  agro-enterprises, 
processors, exporters of raw and value added products, including private sector 
firms not currently involved but with the potential for participation. 
(iii)  Conduct participatory workshops for private sector representatives to identify 
constraints in the business environment to the cultivation of high-value crops and 
agro-processing,  and  to  enhance  the  awareness  of  investors  regarding 
opportunities in agribusiness. 
(iv)  Conduct a detailed review of the institutions involved in the development of 
agribusiness in the public and private sectors, their implementation capacity, and 
the effectiveness of communication between institutions. 
(v)  Assess  the  demand  for  high-value  crops  and  value-added  products  in  the 
domestic and international markets in consultation with the product specialists on 
the team, and identify subsectors with the most growth potential. 
                                                 
1  Including Second Perennial Crops Development Project, approved in 1997; the Southern Province Rural Economic 
Advancement  Project,  approved  in  October  2001;  and  the  Small-  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprise  Sector 
Development Program, approved in December 2001.

Appendix 4  13 
(vi)  Assess the adequacy of infrastructure to support the growth of agribusiness, and 
recommend improvements. 
(vii)  Review the Government policy and legislative framework for agribusiness to 
identify their impact on the growth of the sector, emphasizing policies on seed 
and planting material, plant protection, taxes, and subsidies. 
(viii)  Based on the policy review, identify areas where the public sector can support 
development of the agribusiness sector. 
(ix)  In  consultation  with  the  product  specialists,  design  a  regional  agribusiness 
development plan with priority subsectors identified for each geographic region. 
(x)  Recommend  measures  to  remove  constraints  to  the  adoption  of  appropriate 
high-value crops and value-added products by stakeholders. 
(xi)  In consultation with the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and the Ministry of Agriculture 
Development, propose a redefinition of the “other crops” category in the national 
income statistics to specify subcategories, such as fruits, vegetables, spices, 
floriculture,  and  animal  husbandry,  to  enable  more  effective  monitoring  of 
agribusiness activities. 
(xii)  Study the structure and effectiveness of farmer organizations in major product 
categories, and recommend a suitable farmer organization model.  
(xiii)  Manage the preparation of an agribusiness project, including project objectives, 
components, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, benefits and impact. 
 
3.  Supply  Chain  Management  Specialist  (international,  4  person-months).  The 
consultant will: 
(i)  Assist the team leader in preparing surveys for stakeholder feedback on factors 
that inhibit efficiencies in the marketing chain. 
(ii)  Assess interventions in the agricultural marketing chain to identify reasons for 
success or failure. 
(iii)  Using feedback from surveys, analyze the supply and demand chain for product 
categories  selected  for  their  potential  in  the  sector  to  identify  primary 
inefficiencies,  logistical  barriers,  barriers  to  entry,  and  factors  that  increase 
transaction costs. 
(iv)  Review the marketing arrangements for various types of agribusiness products. 
(v)  Evaluate the adequacy of supportive infrastructure, such as markets, collection 
centers, storage facilities, transport, packaging, and cold chain facilities; and 
recommend improvements to the marketing infrastructure.  
(vi)  Determine  the  adequacy  of  market  intelligence  and  information  systems  for 
agricultural produce; and recommend improvements, including mechanisms for 
the  rapid  transfer  of  price  and  demand  information  to  farmers,  and  the 
dissemination of information on market opportunities. 
(vii)  Recommend improvements to the chain management, including the required 
capacity  development,  vertical  and/or  horizontal  integration,  and 
internationalization. 
(viii)  Recommend  ways  to  facilitate  the  chain  reversal  from  supply-oriented  to 
demand-oriented. 
(ix)  Evaluate the performance of the forward sales contract system initiated by the 
Central Bank of Sri Lanka; and recommend ways to extend it, in the short term, 
to selected crops within the scope of agribusiness development, and, in the 
medium  term,  to  a  potential  commodity  futures  exchange  for  selected 
agribusiness products.

14  Appendix 4 
 
4.  Business Promotion Specialist (international, 4 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Assess  the  willingness  of  private  sector  operators  to  invest  in  agribusiness 
development; identify the scope and potential for such investment; and prepare a 
list of preferred investment areas, in consultation with the product specialists. 
(ii)  Examine the process required to start, register, and operate small and medium 
agribusiness enterprises; and recommend changes to remove barriers to entry. 
(iii)  Review  the  policy,  tax,  trade,  and  regulatory  framework  to  determine  the 
investment appeal for agribusiness development in the business environment; 
and identify factors that inhibit new investment and recommend changes.  
(iv)  Review investment promotion activities undertaken in the country, such as at the 
Board of Investment (BOI); recommend a suitable investment promotion strategy 
for  the  agribusiness  sector  for  local  and  foreign  investors;  and  propose  an 
institutional framework for the strategy. 
(v)  Provide  guidelines  for  the  development  of  tools  of  business  promotion  in 
agribusiness, such as promotional brochures, seminars, and product exhibitions; 
and recommend an implementation program within the proposed institutional 
framework. 
 
5.  Horticulture Specialist (international, 4 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Identify constraints in the horticulture subsector, including access to resources, 
availability and quality of inputs, technology, post-harvest storage, marketing, 
transport, and financial returns to the producer. 
(ii)  Evaluate the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for the development 
of the horticulture subsector.  
(iii)  Assess the demand for high-value fruits, vegetables, and related value-added 
products in the domestic and export markets; identify varieties that have the most 
potential for domestic and export sales, and for increasing domestic value added; 
and assist the economist in preparing concise financial and economic models of 
selected investments.  
(iv)  Assess the potential for organic fruits and vegetables, especially in the export 
markets, and identify areas in the global market that provide opportunities for 
domestic producers.  
(v)  Evaluate  the  available  training  of  producers  and  other  stakeholders  in 
horticulture, and recommend ways to improve the knowledge of farmers and 
processors. 
(vi)  Using  the  findings  from  the  horticulture  subsector  assessment,  formulate  an 
action plan to improve input supplies, production, handling, post-harvest storage, 
transport, and processing of each major category of horticultural products; and 
recommend options for value addition and strategies for the development of 
marketing channels.  
(vii)  Assist  the  business  promotion  specialist  in  preparing  strategies  to  increase 
investment in the horticulture subsector; assist the economist in quantifying the 
costs  and  benefits  of  preparing  concise  financial  and  economic  models  of 
selected investments; and recommend project components to the team leader. 
 
6.  Floriculture Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Identify constraints in the production of floriculture products.

Appendix 4  15 
(ii)  Prepare (a) a detailed market assessment of the varieties of floriculture products 
in which Sri Lanka has a natural advantage; (b) a database of sources of quality 
planting material available globally; and (c) a market development strategy for 
the floriculture industry by specifying marketing channels, such as trade fairs, 
trade journals, direct contact with potential buyers, and international floriculture 
centers for local exporters. 
(iii)  Identify the nature of barriers under plant protection legislation in Sri Lanka that 
discourages the adoption of new planting material for floriculture sourced from 
overseas, and recommend ways to eliminate such barriers. 
(iv)  With  the  assistance  of  the  research  and  extension  services  specialist,  (a) 
examine  the  capability  of  the  Government  research  facilities  to  serve  the 
research needs of the floriculture industry; (b) review the status of the nascent 
private research initiatives in floriculture, and recommend measures for further 
development; and (c) recommend a mechanism for improved communication 
between  the  Government  research  facilities  and  the  floriculture  industry  and 
private research units. 
(v)  Evaluate  the  available  facilities  for  training  producers  in  floriculture,  and 
recommend ways to improve the knowledge of farmers and processors. 
(vi)  Assist  the  business  promotion  specialist  in  preparing  strategies  to  increase 
investment in the floriculture subsector; assist the economist in quantifying the 
costs  and  benefits  of  preparing  concise  financial  and  economic  models  of 
selected investments; and recommend project components to the team leader. 
 
7.  Spices Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Identify constraints in the production of spices in unprocessed and value-added 
form.  
(ii)  Evaluate the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for the development 
of  the  spices  subsector,  including  policies  on  international  trade,  import  of 
planting material, and access to land. 
(iii)  Assess the demand for spices in unprocessed and value-added forms in the 
export markets, taking into consideration current market trends; identify varieties 
that have the most potential for export sales and for increasing domestic value 
added;  and  assist  the  economist  in  quantifying  the  costs  and  benefits  of 
preparing concise financial and economic models of selected investments. 
(iv)  Assess the potential for organic spices, especially in the export markets, and 
identify  areas  in  the  global  market  that  provide  opportunities  for  domestic 
producers. 
(v)  Evaluate the available facilities for training producers in the spices subsector; 
and  recommend  ways  to  improve  the  knowledge  of  farmers,  collectors, 
processors, and exporters. 
(vi)  Formulate an action plan to improve input supplies, production, handling, post-
harvest storage, transport, and processing of spices; recommend options for 
value addition and strategies for the development of markets and marketing 
channels; and recommend ways to improve grading and packaging of spices to 
meet international market standards. 
(vii)  Assist  the  business  promotion  specialist  in  preparing  strategies  to  increase 
investment in the spices subsector; assist the economist in quantifying the costs 
and benefits of preparing concise financial and economic models of selected 
investments; and recommend project components to team leader.

16  Appendix 4 
8.  Livestock and Dairy Specialist (international, 3 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Identify constraints in the production of dairy and other livestock products. 
(ii)  Evaluate the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for the development 
of the livestock sector, including policies on international trade, import of new 
animal stock, and access to land. 
(iii)  Assess the effectiveness of the milk collection system in terms of efficiency and 
returns to the producers; evaluate the structure of milk producer societies serving 
the public and private sector milk processing industries; and identify weaknesses, 
and recommend ways to strengthen the societies. 
(iv)  Examine the supply-and-demand situation and trends for fresh milk and dairy 
products  in  the  domestic  market,  taking  into  consideration  competition  from 
imports; assess the potential for value-added dairy and other livestock products 
in the domestic market; and prepare a priority list of products for investment.  
(v)  Evaluate the available facilities for training producers in the livestock sector, and 
recommend ways to improve the knowledge of all stakeholders.  
(vi)  Formulate  an  action  plan  to  improve  input  supplies,  production,  collection, 
storage, transport, and processing of dairy products and other products in the 
livestock sector. 
(vii)  Assist  the  business  promotion  specialist  in  preparing  strategies  to  increase 
investment in the dairy subsector; assist the economist in quantifying the costs 
and benefits of preparing concise financial and economic models of selected 
investments; and recommend project components to the team leader. 
 
9.  Research  and  Extension  Services  Specialist  (domestic,  4  person-months).  The 
consultant will: 
(i)  Assess the relevance of the public sector research programs to needs, and 
evaluate the responsiveness to demand in establishing research priorities; and 
identify any bias for or against agribusiness in setting research priorities. 
(ii)  Assess the effectiveness of the public sector extension system in meeting the 
requirements  of  the  different  categories  of  farmers  engaged  in  agribusiness 
activities,  and  evaluate  the  effectiveness  of  the  field-level  Agrarian  Service 
Centers in serving the needs of commercial farmers.  
(iii)  Evaluate  the  involvement  of  the  private  sector  in  research  and  extension 
services; draw lessons from continuing and past attempts to involve the private 
sector in the provision of extension services, including the Second Perennial 
Crops  Development  Project  and  the  Southern  Province  Rural  Economic 
Advancement Project;2 and assess the potential for expansion. 
(iv)  Propose public-private partnership models for research and extension services 
that are responsive to the needs of producers.

for the Southern Province Rural Economic Advancement Project. Manila.

Appendix 4  17 
10.  Quality Standards and Certification Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The 
consultant will: 
(i)  Identify the deficiencies in product quality that prevent the development of export 
markets  and  wider  consumer  acceptance  in  the  domestic  market,  and 
recommend actions by stakeholders to improve the quality of produce. 
(ii)  Prepare a list of certification requirements, legislative and market-driven, for the 
products of agribusiness as prioritized by the product specialists; and assemble a 
database of quality standards for relevant products. 
(iii)  Assess the availability of certification agencies domestically, and determine their 
adequacy  with  reference  to  international  norms;  recommend  a  strategy  to 
improve the capacity of national certification agencies; and study the possibility of 
strengthening the capability of producer organizations to undertake certification. 
 
11.  Finance and Credit Specialist (domestic, 4 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Draw lessons from ongoing and past credit schemes for agriculture and small- 
and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SME),  regarding  aspects  such  as  equity  of 
coverage, lending terms and criteria, recovery rates, barriers to borrowing, and 
ease of loan processing; and assess the experience of financial institutions and 
the role played by nongovernment organizations in such schemes.  
(ii)  Study the credit policies of commercial and development banks to assess the 
possibility of expanding lending to agribusiness, and the factors inhibiting the 
commercial banking sector from providing long-term finance. 
(iii)  Design an action plan to enhance the capacity of commercial banks to undertake 
agribusiness lending.  
(iv)  Propose a credit scheme for the agribusiness sector, if needed, emphasizing 
ease of access to agribusiness SMEs. 
 
12.  Economist (domestic, 6 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  With the assistance of the product specialists, prepare concise financial and 
economic models of proposed priority crops and agribusiness investments; and 
identify viable crops and agro-industrial investments that have the most potential 
to improve incomes and living standards in the rural sector, and with the most 
potential for growth. 
(ii)  Prepare  detailed  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  for  the  project,  using 
COSTAB. 
(iii)  Conduct financial and economic analysis of the project, including sensitivity and 
risk analysis; and determine the viability of the project. 
(iv)  Evaluate the distribution of benefits among the different types of stakeholders. 
(v)  Prepare the procurement plan for the ensuing project, in accordance with the 
new Asian Development Bank (ADB) Procurement Guidelines. 
(vi)  Conduct agriculture sector analysis and competitive analysis of the subsectors. 
(vii)  Complete  the  ADB  financial  management  assessment  questionnaire  for 
reviewing the executing and implementing agency’s systems for financial and 
management  accounting,  reporting,  auditing,  and  internal  controls;  and  for 
assessing  whether  the  executing  and  implementing  agency’s  financial 
management  arrangements  are  considered  capable  of,  and  adequate  for, 
recording all transactions and balances, supporting the preparation of regular

18  Appendix 4 
and reliable financial statements, and safeguarding the entity’s assets; and are 
subject to audit (of substance and form acceptable to ADB). 
(viii)  Based on the issues or weaknesses identified during the financial management 
assessment, recommend financial control and other measures (e.g., training and 
institutional  strengthening)  that  could  be  undertaken  during  project 
implementation to ensure that the proceeds of the loan are used only for the 
purposes for which they were granted.  
 
13.  Social Development Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Review  the  effectiveness  of  past  agriculture  sector  projects  in  reaching 
disadvantaged groups and poor smallholders, and recommend approaches for 
including such groups in the project. 
(ii)  Through participatory rural appraisals and focus group discussions, assess why 
youth are not attracted to working in the rural agriculture sector, and provide a 
strategy to mitigate this trend. 
(iii)  Conduct a detailed poverty and social assessment, following the guidelines in the 
ADB‘s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis.  
(iv)  Assess the potential impacts of agribusiness development on poverty reduction 
in the country. 
(v)  Screen for land acquisition and involuntary resettlement issues, if needed. 
(vi)  Assess gender issues and the role of women in agribusiness activities, and 
recommend measures to address gender in all components of the project. 
 
14.  Environmentalist (domestic, 2 person-months). The consultant will: 
(i)  Review  the  environmental  impact  of  crop  production  systems  and  agro-
processing industries, and identify practices that harm the environment. 
(ii)  Evaluate  the  extent  and  impact  of  project  activities;  and  prepare  an  initial 
environmental examination in accordance with the ADB's Environment Policy and 
environmental guidelines, as well as the country guidelines for the environment. 
(iii)  Evaluate the potential and recommend measures to reuse by-products or waste 
products of the agro-industrial projects in an environmentally sound manner. 
(iv)  Recommend mitigation measures and monitoring programs, estimate their share 
of  project  cost,  develop  environmental  guidelines  for  selected  project 
components,  and  specify  an  institutional  framework  for  monitoring  the 
environmental impact. 
 
15.  Workshops and Consultations Facilitator (domestic, intermittent, 2 person-months). 
The consultant will: 
(i)  Assist team members in planning and organizing stakeholder workshops during 
the TA. 
(ii)  Serve as facilitator at the workshops and focus group discussions, and evaluate 
the power relations between the players in the value chain.
